comments.commentBody:
Wow it's getting hard to keep up with replies. Many thanks to dear Miss Ley, and clever Blue State, and honorable Richard Luettgen, and my Maine man Eric, and Margaret, Kristine, Expat Annie, Glen, Elizabeth, all of y'all and more. I appreciate the feedback, lots to be thankful for this Thanksgiving.

I'm honored to be praised by you intelligent, wise people. As to the green checks, I expect not to get one because sometimes my comments are outrageous; I write all in a burst and hardly ever edit. As to the oft-remarked on notion of the liberal/conservative divide, I've got thoughts on that too, naturally.

We're not really liberal nor conservative. We're individuals, all with different outlooks and experiences. More liberal people are drawn to the NYT, but plenty of conservatives, and the real thing that draws us is intelligence. This is not a place of propaganda or dumbing-down, there's a lot of analysis going on, and we like it.

I myself am mainly liberal but have diverged quite a lot from the norm; as Miss Ley says I'd rather tigers ate people than people hunted tigers. I'm pro-2nd amendment too (much to many's dismay), and anti-illegal immigrant, as actually a lot of us technical liberals are. And I've seen 'liberals' here be fully against the Palestinians, or unregulated abortion, or legal marijuana, lots of standard liberal stuff.

So I'd advise don't rush to pigeonhole people, discuss things on the merits. Thanks again all for reading and writing :)

This is America--
everything is a race with pincers
and a furious pace.

You are right--if you are a Johnny come lately your approval rating will not match that bestowed on the early birds. That is the nature of the game. If you're not there when the starting gate opens and the pistol sounds you are unread and unsung. But who cares! The pleasure is in unburdening what's on the chest. If only one other reader gets you that is approval one better than what you would have had, had you never spoken. Better still is dissent, provocative and disputatious coming from someone who sees your comment as all clay feet and irredeemable. To face that challenge is even better than numerous upticks earned or the warm embrace of the NYT editors making you their pick of the day.

Back in the early 90s I had a file folder of unpublished/unsent letters to the NY Times editor. Then I had a hard drive of them. I'd debate whether to send them, and once sent would wonder if they'd been published. The process took weeks.

Now I can make these comments, know at least few people will read them, and get on with my day!

"...no personal attacks"?

What is this, communism?
That is called hitting the nail on the NYT head.
People are going to spend as long as advertisers can produce TV spots. That is what we do here. They may quit buying new cars but they all have to be fixed and need fuel.

Exactly - if you skip many of the "top" commenters, you won't lose much discussion that is actually sharing uncovered facts, imparting genuinely new wisdom. It less feels like a place where people want vigorous, dissenting discussion and more where there's lazy, voluble meandering.

And I don't share the fandom for Mr Eisenberg's limericks. Having them appear monotonically near the start of every comments section (for example) in a Dowd article - what is the point? To inject ham-fisted humor in a fundamentally political discussion? To divert with entertainment? When repeated so relentlessly, it has the effect of stating "none of this important" and trivializes the original story.

Understandably, the urge to speak and be heard is natural. The NYT comments section is not yet like the section of the WAPost (where story threads degrade to the point of people discussing their weekend plans) or Salon (food fights). But it shouldn't become - as Chekhov wrote about a similar group in his time - a Club of Contented Idiots.

Sure, of course, fine. But what about me?

I'll chime in here.

I think the problem with the Kurds and the Turks is that, since Ataturk, Turkey has been trying to impose a unitary state system on what clearly is not a unitary state, and Kurds aren't the only people inside Turkey that aren't Turks.

The solution, I think is to take a look at a peninsula on the other end of the Mediterranean sea, i.e. Spain. Spain has a floating point federalism - where there are various different regions that all have a different arrangement (thus 'floating point') with the central government.

A solution is to put all of Kurdistan, save the Iranian section, into Turkey on a floating point arrangement, and perhaps acknowledge other regions as well. Then make getting along a condition for continued access and association to the European Union and NATO security.

The Evolution of Cooperation (Robert Axelrod) teaches two things.
Cooperation to exist requires a perpetual relationship AND opportunity (i.e. benefit from cooperation). You must have both. European style prosperity and security which is what Western Turkey now seems to enjoy, can be made the benefit.

The map should be redrawn too. Northern Iraq should be enveloped into the new arrangement. History shows that control of Eastern Anatolia + Northern Iraq (where some of Histories most decisive battles have been fought - Manzikert, Gaugamela) is necessary for control of Syria, Palestine & Egypt. If we want those places to be nurtured by the west, then this redrawing is necessary.
Perhaps the merger will ensure the availability of hitherto unavailable falcon-flavored mousse?  Now that would give the whiners real bragging rights...

I'm signed up for both Starwood and Marriott, but in the end I stayed with Marriott as my go to place. There are wide ranges in hotels offered through both chains, but the bottom in Marriott is far higher than the bottom in Starwood. You don't always get to upscale when you travel, but when you find your self with only the bottom of the heap to pick from, I found Marriott always offers a good nights rest in a comfortable room. Starwood, sometimes, meh?
Marriott's upper tier is superlative. Looking forward to my Marriott signature hotel vacation this year, on Hawaii.

All the brands mentioned are mostly mid range business hotels.  This is not where one finds real luxury.  Regardless, with hotels as with airlines, the points games are drawing to a close.  Time to cash in one's chips with all of them, and stop chasing "elite" tiers that offer very little.

In AZ - Charter Schools tend to be profit centers not teaching centers.  I am all for coming up with new ways to improve education - they should be non-profit and the CEO's income should be in line with a principal - not a district superintend.

I used to comment frequently on these boards for the reasons similar to that which Bruce Rozenblit mentioned: To participate in democracy, exercise my free speech rights, & compete in the marketplace of ideas.

In fact, I've always frequently changed my screen name and login, bc I feel strongly that it's one's IDEAS (and to a lesser extent my words) that should matter, not who one is. I want to my ideas to stand alone, without the confounding factors of personality, reputation, demographics and identity politics.

I also have little respect for ad hominem attacks, & I find that posting anonymously -- under an unfamiliar screen name and with a non-informative placeholder for the location -- generally cuts down on the number of ad hominems I receive from commenters who disagree with me.

I rarely comment here anymore, however, because of repeated instances in which I spent time and thought crafting a comment, only to see it vanish into the ether. Sometimes this was because the moderator cut it (probably because my tone was too abrasive or cynical, or my ideas too extreme or outre), but far more often, it was bc the moderator closed the board to commenting (the timing seems random) while I was mid-sentence. Even more maddeningly, the board would sometimes *reopen* a day or two later, but with only those comments submitted after the reopening being published.

Now I exercise my right to free speech & participate in democracy on Twitter. (Now watch this comment get the ax.)

This is why the kids that go to charter schools do better--they do not have to endure the constant distractions of a typical public school classroom mix. The administrators don't want to remove the mentally ill/troubled/traumatized kids probably because they don't have anywhere to put them and no help to offer them. Charters do what the public schools are not allowed to do--separate out the kids who want to/can learn and focus on them. Of course they do better. They are motivated/healthy and in an environment with other motivated/healthy students.

I love reading Motherlode, commenting and interacting with the readers. It's mainly because of the wisdom of writers, many commentators and very few comments per article barring a few. Another biggest advantage is that articles are always brief. Further, it's beautifully managed by KJ Dell' Antonia.

The advantage of few comments per article is that one can go through all the comments without missing or bypassing any and one can thoroughly understand, appreciate and enjoy though not follow the wisdom since it's easy to appreciate but very difficult to implement the same in one's life.

The problem with the hundreds or thousands of comments is that it's extremely difficult to navigate. It so happens, the reader in all probability will miss some of the wonderful comments, more so in the case of those comments, which no one liked or having one or two likes.

Coming to the main section, Republican Party bashers are found left, right and centre in topics like politics, foreign affairs, education, parenting, wars, global warming, money etc. They get maximum likes even upto a thousand or more but they have precious little to say on the issue that matters.

As far as Motherlode commentators are concerned I love to see Banty figure in the top list though some others are also my favourites. As far as global warming issue is concerned. My vote overwhelmingly goes in favour of Susan Anderson.

New York Times will do better if it's restricted to constructive criticism.

So, I take it you haven't read David Brooks, a fairly conservative guy,
or Ross Douthat, a very conservative guy, both columnists for the
New York Times.
And I always seem to notice the many, many commenters from points far from NYC, including foreign countries. But they do add many insights and nuances to the thoughtlines.

LOL, the backspace key is your friend. It turns "David Brooks should crawl back under the rock and rejoin his fellow creatures unchanged since before the age of dinosaurs" to "In suggesting that starving orphans meditate upon their good fortune, David Brooks unintentionally betrayed the good intentions that he undoubtedly brought to today's column."
So that's why I've not been seeing you of late! You were missed!

I agree that it is important to hear from parents whose children are in foster care or have been adopted. I have seen articles written by people in this position on Motherlode.

I don't understand the problem with those stories not being part of this specific series which, like all of the other Diary series in the Motherlode column (Fertility Diary, Deployment Diary, Preschool Admissions Diary, etc.) is written from the perspective of someone experiencing the topic at hand. The Foster Parent Diary, following this pattern, is written from the point of view of one foster parent. Ms. Walbert is no doubt aware of the importance of protecting the privacy of BlueJay's biological family especially since she is writing a series of first-person essays as opposed to performing investigative journalism. The other side of the story is extremely valuable too; perhaps Motherlode will run a Birth Parent Diary one day. In the meantime, Ms. Walbert writes about her own role with sensitivity and grace.

And yes, it's very important for the biological parents to access help for any issues. The goal of foster care is reunification; caseworkers work with biological families too. Should interventions benefit only the child and biological family and "not the foster family" though? I'm not sure why they have to be mutually exclusive. While a child is being cared for by a foster family, the foster family can receive some support as they in turn support the child and his/her reunification.

The Buddy:

Don't know how old you are, but I'm 60. Most of the better known commenters here are my age or older. When I was much younger I was almost as erudite but far less generally knowledgeable than I am now. I kept my mouth shut because it was offensive to many that a younger person show arrogance at having a good processor but only a partially filled database. Well, at 60 I still have a good processor but now I have a well-filled database.

Time for some arrogance. I can't wait until I'm in my late 70s or even 80s, should I remain vertical that long, so I can, with impunity, start whacking people's legs.
Thanks so much, Fast&Furious!

I've seen a couple of commenters who use the same rhetoric as jihadists and no conflicting comments are ever allowed. I understand getting all perspectives, but should we really give a platform for that kind of evil? ISIS has "glossy" magazines for that. Well actually, once, Dan Stackhouse was allowed to respond (Thank you Dan). There was one commenter who had an incredible knowledge of the Middle East, but I believe they became disillusioned by the disinformation campaign by those who sound like they are part of the ISIS propaganda machine and those who buy their propaganda.
As much as I abhor that kind of anti-Semitism, it is an opinion, and I think it's important to know that it's out there and to have an opportunity to refute it as necessary.

The criteria used by the human moderators remain mysterious. Last week, for example, I noticed 2 comments blaming Jews for the invasion of Iraq, which I would have thought moderators would not permit.

In addition, as with many debates about the Times' staffers, I wonder how the moderators' political affiliations compare to those of the US as a whole.

Finally, because Times readers are often so eloquent, I regret that the book reviews do not feature comments--including comments by the authors being reviewed, which I suspect would be more numerous than those printed in the letters to the editor.
